Line 15: Line 15:
Many settlers immediately started improving their new land or stood in line waiting to file their claim. Many children sold creek water to [[homesteader]]s waiting in line for five cents a cup, while other children gathered [[buffalo chip]]s to provide fuel for cooking. By the second week, schools had opened and were being taught by volunteers paid by pupils' parents until regular school districts could be established. Within one month, Oklahoma City had five banks and six papers.<ref name="eitunassi">{{cite web |url=http://www.rootsweb.com/%7Eitunassi/index.html |title=History of the Unassigned Lands |accessdate=2007-03-04 |date=2007-01-02}}</ref>
Many settlers immediately started improving their new land or stood in line waiting to file their claim. Many children sold creek water to [[homesteader]]s waiting in line for five cents a cup, while other children gathered [[buffalo chip]]s to provide fuel for cooking. By the second week, schools had opened and were being taught by volunteers paid by pupils' parents until regular school districts could be established. Within one month, Oklahoma City had five banks and six papers.<ref name="eitunassi">{{cite web |url=http://www.rootsweb.com/%7Eitunassi/index.html |title=History of the Unassigned Lands |accessdate=2007-03-04 |date=2007-01-02}}</ref>
â
On [[May 2]], [[1890]], the [[Organic Act]] was passed creating the [[Oklahoma Territory]]. This act included the [[Oklahoma Panhandle|Panhandle]] of Oklahoma within the territory. It also allowed for central governments and designated [[Guthrie, Oklahoma|Guthrie]] as the territory's capital.<ref name="eitunassi"/> & axzaly wuz hurr.
+
On [[May 2]], [[1890]], the [[Organic Act]] was passed creating the [[Oklahoma Territory]]. This act included the [[Oklahoma Panhandle|Panhandle]] of Oklahoma within the territory. It also allowed for central governments and designated [[Guthrie, Oklahoma|Guthrie]] as the territory's capital.<ref name="eitunassi"/>
